section.title: The span of a set of vectors

introduction.p: Our work in this chapter enables us to rewrite a linear system in the form A\xvec = \bvec. Besides being a more compact way of expressing a linear system, this form allows us to think about linear systems geometrically since matrix multiplication is defined in terms of linear combinations of vectors.

We now return, in this and the next section, to the two fundamental questions asked in .
Existence: Is there a solution to the equation A\xvec=\bvec?
Uniqueness: If there is a solution to the equation A\xvec=\bvec, is it unique?
In this section, we focus on the existence question and introduce the concept of span to provide a framework for thinking about it geometrically.

li.p: If the equation A\xvec = \bvec is inconsistent, what can we say about the pivots of the augmented matrix \left[\begin{array}{r|r} A \amp \bvec \end{array}\right]?

Consider the matrix A
A = \left[ \begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ -2 \amp 2 \amp 2 \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp -3 \end{array}\right] . If \bvec=\threevec{2}{2}{5}, is the equation A\xvec = \bvec consistent? If so, find a solution.
If \bvec=\threevec{2}{2}{6}, is the equation A\xvec = \bvec consistent? If so, find a solution.
Identify the pivot positions of A.
For our two choices of the vector \bvec, one equation A\xvec = \bvec has a solution and the other does not. What feature of the pivot positions of the matrix A tells us to expect this?
We know there must be a pivot in the rightmost column of the augmented matrix.

Now the augmented matrix is
\left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp -2 \amp 2 \\ -2 \amp 2 \amp 2 \amp 2 \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp -3 \amp 6 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp -2 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \end{array}\right]
showing that the equation A\xvec=\bvec is inconsistent.

There are two pivot positions in A, as shown.
\left[\begin{array}{rrr} {\mathbf 1} \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ -2 \amp {\mathbf 2} \amp 2 \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp -3 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr} {\mathbf 1} \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp {\mathbf 1} \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.}

Since there is a row of A that does not have a pivot position, it is possible to augment A by a vector \bvec so that we obtain a pivot position in the rightmost column of the augmented matrix. In this case, we have an inconsistent system.

subsection.title: The span of a set of vectors
subsection.p: In the preview activity, we considered a 3\times3 matrix A and found that the equation A\xvec = \bvec has a solution for some vectors \bvec in \real^3 and has no solution for others. We will introduce a concept called span that describes the vectors \bvec for which there is a solution.

Since we would like to think about this concept geometrically, we will consider an m\times n matrix A as being composed of n vectors in \real^m; that is,
A = \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} \vvec_1\amp\vvec_2\amp\ldots\amp\vvec_n \end{array}\right] . Remember that says that the equation A\xvec = \bvec is consistent if and only if we can express \bvec as a linear combination of \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n.

definition.p: The span of a set of vectors \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n is the set of all linear combinations of the vectors.

subsection.p:
In other words, the span of \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n consists of all the vectors \bvec for which the equation
\left[\begin{array}{rrrr} \vvec_1\amp\vvec_2\amp\ldots\amp\vvec_n \end{array}\right] \xvec = \bvec
is consistent.

The span of a set of vectors has an appealing geometric interpretation. Remember that we may think of a linear combination as a recipe for walking in \real^m. We first move a prescribed amount in the direction of \vvec_1, then a prescribed amount in the direction of \vvec_2, and so on. As the following activity will show, the span consists of all the places we can walk to.

statement.p:
Let's look at two examples to develop some intuition for the concept of span.
First, we will consider the set of vectors
\vvec = \twovec{1}{2}, \wvec = \twovec{-2}{-4} .
Linear combinations of vectors \vvec and \wvec.
The diagram below can be used to construct linear combinations whose weights a and b may be varied using the sliders at the top. The vectors \vvec and \wvec are drawn in gray while the linear combination
a\vvec + b\wvec
is in red.
What vector is the linear combination of \vvec and \wvec with weights:
a = 2 and b=0?
a = 1 and b=1?
a = 0 and b=-1?
Can the vector \twovec{2}{4} be expressed as a linear combination of \vvec and \wvec? Is the vector \twovec{2}{4} in the span of \vvec and \wvec?
Can the vector \twovec{3}{0} be expressed as a linear combination of \vvec and \wvec? Is the vector \twovec{3}{0} in the span of \vvec and \wvec?
Describe the set of vectors in the span of \vvec and \wvec.
For what vectors \bvec does the equation
\left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp -2 \\ 2 \amp -4 \end{array}\right] \xvec = \bvec
have a solution?
We will now look at an example where
\vvec = \twovec{2}{1}, \wvec = \twovec{1}{2} .
Linear combinations of vectors \vvec and \wvec.
In a similar way, the diagram below can be used to construct linear combinations
a\vvec + b\wvec.
The diagram below can be used to construct linear combinations whose weights a and b may be varied using the sliders at the top. The vectors \vvec and \wvec are drawn in gray while the linear combination
a\vvec + b\wvec
is in red.
What vector is the linear combination of \vvec and \wvec with weights:
a = 2 and b=0?
a = 1 and b=1?
a = 0 and b=-1?
Can the vector \twovec{-2}{2} be expressed as a linear combination of \vvec and \wvec? Is the vector \twovec{-2}{2} in the span of \vvec and \wvec?
Can the vector \twovec{3}{0} be expressed as a linear combination of \vvec and \wvec? Is the vector \twovec{3}{0} in the span of \vvec and \wvec?
Describe the set of vectors in the span of \vvec and \wvec.
For what vectors \bvec does the equation
\left[\begin{array}{rr} 2 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 2 \end{array}\right] \xvec = \bvec
have a solution?

li.p:
For the first set of vectors, we find:
We can form the linear combinations:
When a = 2 and b=0, the linear combination is \twovec{2}{4}.
When a = 1 and b=1, the linear combination is \twovec{-2}{-4}.
When a = 0 and b=-1, the linear combination is \twovec{2}{4}.
Yes. We saw that there are at least two ways; for instance, when the weights are a=2 and b=0. This means that \twovec{2}{4} is in the span of \vvec and \wvec.
No. No matter how we change the weights, the linear combination lies on the line through \vvec and \wvec. This means that \twovec{3}{0} is not in the span of \vvec and \wvec.
The span of \vvec and \wvec is the set of all vectors on the line through \vvec.
If the equation has a solution, \bvec must be a scalar multiple of \vvec.

For the second set of vectors, we have:
We can form the linear combinations:
When a = 2 and b=0, the linear combination is \twovec{2}{4}.
When a = 1 and b=1, the linear combination is \twovec{3}{3}.
When a = 0 and b=-1, the linear combination is \twovec{-1}{-2}.
Yes. Using the diagram, we see that \twovec{-2}{2}=-2\vvec + 2\wvec. This means that \twovec{-2}{2} is in the span of \vvec and \wvec.
Yes. Using the diagram, we see that \twovec{3}{0}=2\vvec-1\wvec. This means that \twovec{3}{0} is in the span of \vvec and \wvec.
Every two-dimensional vector is in the span of \vvec and \wvec.
The equation has a solution for every \bvec.

subsection.p: Let's consider the first example in the previous activity. Here, the vectors \vvec and \wvec are scalar multiples of one another, which means that they lie on the same line. When we form linear combinations, we are allowed to walk only in the direction of \vvec and \wvec, which means we are constrained to stay on this same line. Therefore, the span of \vvec and \wvec consists only of this line.

caption.p: With this choice of vectors \vvec and \wvec, all linear combinations lie on the line shown. This line, therefore, is the span of the vectors \vvec and \wvec.

subsection.p:
We may see this algebraically since the vector \wvec = -2\vvec. Consequently, when we form a linear combination of \vvec and \wvec, we see that
\begin{aligned} a\vvec + b\wvec \amp {}={} a\vvec + b(-2\vvec) \\ \amp {}={} (a-2b)\vvec \\ \end{aligned} . Therefore, any linear combination of \vvec and \wvec reduces to a scalar multiple of \vvec, and we have seen that the scalar multiples of a nonzero vector form a line.
In the second example, however, the vectors are not scalar multiples of one another, and we see that we can construct any vector in \real^2 as a linear combination of \vvec and \wvec.

caption.p: With this choice of vectors \vvec and \wvec, we are able to form any vector in \real^2 as a linear combination. Therefore, the span of the vectors \vvec and \wvec is the entire plane, \real^2.

subsection.p:
The augmented matrix for this system is
\left[\begin{array}{rr|r} 2 \amp 1 \amp * \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp * \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp * \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp * \\ \end{array}\right] . Since it is impossible to obtain a pivot in the rightmost column, we know that this system is consistent no matter what the vector \bvec is. Therefore, every vector \bvec in \real^2 is in the span of \vvec and \wvec.

In this case, notice that the reduced row echelon form of the matrix
\left[\begin{array}{rr} \vvec \amp \wvec \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 2 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 2 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right]
has a pivot in every row. When this happens, it is not possible for any augmented matrix to have a pivot in the rightmost column. Therefore, the linear system is consistent for every vector \bvec, which implies that the span of \vvec and \wvec is \real^2.

convention.p: We will denote the span of the set of vectors \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n by \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n}.

subsection.title: Pivot positions and span
subsection.p: In the previous activity, we saw two examples, both of which considered two vectors \vvec and \wvec in \real^2. In one example, the \laspan{\vvec,\wvec} consisted of a line; in the other, the \laspan{\vvec,\wvec}=\real^2. We would like to be able to distinguish these two situations in a more algebraic fashion. After all, we will need to be able to deal with vectors in many more dimensions where we will not be able to draw pictures.

The key is found by looking at the pivot positions of the matrix \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} \vvec_1\amp\vvec_2\amp\ldots\vvec_n \end{array}\right] . In the first example, the matrix whose columns are \vvec and \wvec is
\left[\begin{array}{rr} 1\amp -2 \\ 2\amp -4 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rr} 1\amp -2 \\ 0\amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] , which has exactly one pivot position. We found the \laspan{\vvec,\wvec} to be a line, in this case.

In the second example, this matrix is
\left[\begin{array}{rr} 2\amp 1 \\ 1\amp 2 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rr} 1\amp 0 \\ 0\amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] , which has two pivot positions. Here, we found \laspan{\vvec,\wvec}=\real^2.

These examples point to the fact that the size of the span is related to the number of pivot positions. We will develop this idea more fully in and . For now, however, we will examine the possibilities in \real^3.

statement.p:
In this activity, we will look at the span of sets of vectors in \real^3.
Suppose v=\threevec{1}{2}{1}. Give a written description of \laspan{v} and a rough sketch of it below.
Consider now the two vectors
\evec_1 = \threevec{1}{0}{0}, \evec_2 = \threevec{0}{1}{0} . Sketch the vectors below. Then give a written description of \laspan{\evec_1,\evec_2} and a rough sketch of it below.
Let's now look at this algebraically by writing write \bvec = \threevec{b_1}{b_2}{b_3}. Determine the conditions on b_1, b_2, and b_3 so that \bvec is in \laspan{\evec_1,\evec_2} by considering the linear system
\left[\begin{array}{rr} \evec_1 \amp \evec_2 \\ \end{array}\right] \xvec = \bvec
or
\left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] \xvec = \threevec{b_1}{b_2}{b_3} . Explain how this relates to your sketch of \laspan{\evec_1,\evec_2}.
Consider the vectors
\vvec_1 = \threevec{1}{1}{-1}, \vvec_2 = \threevec{0}{2}{1} .
Is the vector \bvec=\threevec{1}{-2}{4} in \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2}?
Is the vector \bvec=\threevec{-2}{0}{3} in \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2}?
Give a written description of \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2}.
Consider the vectors
\vvec_1 = \threevec{1}{1}{-1}, \vvec_2 = \threevec{0}{2}{1}, \vvec_3 = \threevec{1}{-2}{4} . Form the matrix \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \vvec_3 \end{array}\right] and find its reduced row echelon form.
What does this tell you about \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3}?
If a set of vectors \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n spans \real^3, what can you say about the pivots of the matrix \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} \vvec_1\amp\vvec_2\amp\ldots\amp\vvec_n \end{array}\right]?
What is the smallest number of vectors such that \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n} = \real^3?

li.p:
We consider the two cases.
We have the augmented matrix
\left[\begin{array}{rr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp -2 \\ -1 \amp 1 \amp 4 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \end{array}\right]\text{,}
which shows that the system is inconsistent. Therefore, \bvec is not in \laspan{\vvec_1, \vvec_2}.
We have the augmented matrix
\left[\begin{array}{rr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ -1 \amp 1 \amp 3 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \end{array}\right]\text{,}
which shows that the system is consistent. Therefore, \bvec is in \laspan{\vvec_1, \vvec_2}.
The span is the plane in \real^3 defined by \vvec_1 and \vvec_2.
There must be a pivot position in every row.
The smallest number of vectors that span \real^3 is three.

subsection.p:
This activity shows us the types of sets that can appear as the span of a set of vectors in \real^3.
First, with a single vector, all linear combinations are simply scalar multiples of that vector, which creates a line.
Notice that the matrix formed by this vector has one pivot, just as in our earlier example in \real^2.
\threevec{1}{2}{1} \sim \threevec{1}{0}{0} .
When we consider linear combinations of the vectors
\evec_1 = \threevec{1}{0}{0}, \evec_2 = \threevec{0}{1}{0} , we must obtain vectors of the form
a\evec_1 + b\evec_2 = a\threevec{1}{0}{0}+b\threevec{0}{1}{0} = \threevec{a}{b}{0} . Since the third component is zero, these vectors form the plane z=0.
Notice here that the matrix composed of the vectors has two pivot positions.
\left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] .
Similarly, the span of the vectors
\vvec_1 = \threevec{1}{1}{-1}, \vvec_2 = \threevec{0}{2}{1} , will form a plane.
We saw one vector \bvec that was not in \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2} and one that is.
Once again, the matrix
\left[\begin{array}{rr} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp 0 \\ 1 \amp 2 \\ -1 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right]
has two pivot positions.
Finally, we looked at a set of vectors whose matrix
\left[\begin{array}{rrr} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \vvec_3 \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp -2 \\ -1 \amp 1 \amp 4 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right]
has three pivot positions, one in every row. This is significant because it means that if we consider an augmented matrix
\left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp *\\ 1 \amp 2 \amp -2 \amp * \\ -1 \amp 1 \amp 4 \amp * \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp *\\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp * \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp * \\ \end{array}\right] , there cannot be a pivot position in the rightmost column. This linear system is consistent for every vector \bvec, which tells us that \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3} = \real^3.

To summarize, we looked at the pivot positions in the matrix whose columns were the vectors \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n. We found that with
one pivot position, the span was a line.
two pivot positions, the span was a plane.
three pivot positions, the span was \real^3.

Once again, we will develop these ideas more fully in the next and subsequent sections. However, we saw that, when considering vectors in \real^3, a pivot position in every row implied that the span of the vectors is \real^3. The same reasoning applies more generally.

statement.p: Suppose we have vectors \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n in \real^m. Then \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n}=\real^m if and only if the matrix \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} \vvec_1\amp\vvec_2\amp\ldots\amp\vvec_n \end{array}\right] has a pivot position in every row.

subsection.p:
This tells us something important about the number of vectors needed to span \real^m. Suppose we have n vectors \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n that span \real^m. The proposition tells us that the matrix A = \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} \vvec_1\amp\vvec_2\ldots\vvec_n \end{array}\right] has a pivot position in every row, such as in this reduced row echelon matrix.
\left[\begin{array}{rrrrrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp * \amp 0 \amp * \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp * \amp 0 \amp * \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp * \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] . Since a matrix can have at most one pivot position in a column, there must be at least as many columns as there are rows, which implies that n\geq m.
For instance, if we have a set of vectors that span \real^{632}, there must be at least 632 vectors in the set.

statement.p: If a set of vectors span \real^m, there must be at least m vectors in the set.

subsection.p: This makes sense intuitively. We have thought about a linear combination of a set of vectors \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n as the result of walking a certain distance in the direction of \vvec_1, followed by walking a certain distance in the direction of \vvec_2, and so on. If \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n} = \real^m, this means that we can walk to any point in \real^m using the directions \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n. It makes sense that we would need at least m directions to give us the flexibilty needed to reach any point in \real^m.

subsection.title: Summary
subsection.p:
We defined the span of a set of vectors and developed some intuition for this concept through a series of examples.
The span of a set of vectors \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n is the set of linear combinations of the vectors. We denote the span by \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n}.
A vector \bvec is in \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n} if an only if the linear system
\left[\begin{array}{rrrr} \vvec_1\amp\vvec_2\amp\ldots\vvec_n \end{array}\right] \xvec = \bvec
is consistent.
If the m\times n matrix
\left[\begin{array}{rrrr} \vvec_1\amp\vvec_2\amp\ldots\vvec_n \end{array}\right]
has a pivot in every row, then the span of these vectors is \real^m; that is, \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n} = \real^m.
Any set of vectors that spans \real^m must have at least m vectors.
